# Draft:Battle of Badhangarh

In an attempt to expand the Chand dynasty’s dominion in the Himalayan foothills, King Rudra Chand of Kumaon ordered his commander Purush Pant to capture Badhangarh Fort in the pargana of Badhan, a territory held by the Garhwal Kingdom under King Dularai Shah.
Aware of the impending invasion, Dularai Shah forged an alliance with Sukaldeo, the last feudatory king of the declining Katyuri dynasty. In return for military support, Dularai Shah promised Sukaldeo assistance against the growing threat of the Chand rulers.
The Battle
As Purush Pant’s army advanced through the Katyur valley, Sukaldeo strategically cut off their supply lines, weakening the invading forces. The Garhwal army, reinforced by local warriors called Padyars, confronted the Chand troops.
In the ensuing battle, a Garhwali soldier fatally wounded Purush Pant by hurling a spear (bhuriya). After his death, the Padyars severed his head and, as per the king's orders, transported it in stages (charit charit) to King Dularai Shah . In return, those who carried the head were rewarded with villages as fiefs at their halts.
Aftermath
The initial Garhwal victory enraged Rudra Chand, who promptly organized a retaliatory campaign. He marched on Katyur, captured Sukaldeo, and later released him on parole with a promise secured by a local noble, Ratu Bora of Baurrarau. However, when the terms were not met, Rudra Chand re-invaded Katyur.
In the subsequent conflict, Sukaldeo and Ratu were executed, and Katyur was annexed to the Chand kingdom of Kumaon. Rudra Chand then consolidated his rule, extending the Chand dynasty’s influence further across the region.
Significance
The Battle of Badhangarh was a pivotal event in the medieval history of Kumaon and Garhwal:
* It marked the decline of the independent Katyuri dynasty.
* It demonstrated the military resilience of the Garhwal kingdom in defending its territories.
* The battle and its aftermath reflected the political ruthlessness and territorial ambition of Rudra Chand.
